security_audit.summary: This is a legitimate Playwright web testing skill. All 341 static findings are false positives triggered by benign testing patterns. The skill uses standard browser automation for test isolation (localStorage clearing), environment configuration (dotenv loading), screenshot capture (visual regression testing), and network interception (API mocking). No evidence of malicious intent, credential exfiltration, or unauthorized network connections found.

content.value_statement: Manual browser testing is slow and error-prone. This skill provides automated end-to-end testing with Playwright for reliable cross-browser validation, form testing, and visual regression checks.
actual_capabilities: Create end-to-end tests for web applications across Chromium, Firefox, and WebKit browsers
Automate form interactions including validation, file uploads, and multi-step workflows
Mock API responses and intercept network requests for controlled testing scenarios
Test mobile responsive designs with device emulation for iPhone, Pixel, and other devices
Capture screenshots and videos for debugging test failures and visual regression
Implement Page Object Model pattern for maintainable and reusable test code
limitations: Requires Playwright and browser installations to execute tests
Tests run in isolated browser contexts and do not modify host system files
Visual regression testing requires external image comparison library like Pillow
Test code must be written in Python or JavaScript following Playwright patterns

prompt_templates.title: Basic Page Test
prompt_templates.prompt: Write a Playwright test that navigates to example.com and verifies the page title and h1 text match expected values.

prompt_templates.title: Form Interaction
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a Playwright test for a contact form that fills name, email, and message fields, then submits and checks for success message.

prompt_templates.title: API Mocking
prompt_templates.prompt: Write a test that intercepts the /api/user endpoint and returns mock JSON data, then verifies the UI displays the mocked user information.

prompt_templates.title: Mobile Responsive
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a Playwright test using iPhone 12 device emulation that verifies the mobile menu appears and navigation works on smaller viewports.

output_examples.input: Write a test for shopping cart checkout flow
output: Adds product to cart from product page

output_examples.input: Create a visual regression test for the homepage
output: Waits for page to fully load

best_practices: Use test IDs and semantic selectors instead of fragile CSS selectors tied to page structure
Leverage Playwright auto-waiting instead of manual sleep statements for reliable tests
Clear cookies and localStorage between tests to ensure complete test isolation
anti_patterns: Avoid hardcoded sleep delays which cause flaky tests and slow execution
Do not use position-based selectors like div:nth-child(3) that break on layout changes
Avoid test interdependencies where one test requires another to run first

faq.question: Which browsers does this skill support?
faq.answer: Playwright supports Chromium, Firefox, and WebKit for comprehensive cross-browser testing with a unified API.

faq.question: What are the resource limits for tests?
faq.answer: Tests run in isolated browser contexts. Memory and CPU depend on the host system capabilities for browser execution.

faq.question: Can I integrate with CI/CD systems?
faq.answer: Yes. The skill includes GitHub Actions and Docker examples for running tests in CI/CD pipelines.

faq.question: Is my test data kept private?
faq.answer: Tests run locally in isolated browser contexts. No test data is sent to external servers.

faq.question: Why are my tests failing intermittently?
faq.answer: Flaky tests often result from missing waits. Use Playwright auto-waiting and expect assertions.

faq.question: How does this compare to Selenium or Cypress?
faq.answer: Playwright offers faster execution, better auto-waiting, and native multi-browser support with unified API.
